docs.lead_paragraph: They call themselves a league of nations, this group of workers who trudge day after day outside the Domino Sugar refinery, a Brooklyn landmark that towers like a fortress over the East River, a monument to New York's great industrial past. The workers, 300 men and women from Poland, Italy, Jamaica and a dozen other nations, have defied the scorching summer sun and winter winds since going on strike eight months ago, resisting concessions demanded by the refinery, one of the last large manufacturing plants in Brooklyn.

headline.main: At Sugar Refinery, A Melting-Pot Strike; Workers of Many Nations Besiege Brooklyn Relic of Industrial Age

docs.abstract: Strike by workers at Domino Sugar refinery in Brooklyn enters its eighth month; strikers, represented by International Longshoreman's Assn, have stuck together despite different ages and accents, with no one crossing picket line since strike began; Domino dispute has turned into classic labor standoff between blue-collar work force intent on defending protections and benefits it took decades to gain and company that insists it needs to cut costs to remain competitive; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: They had little or nothing in common. And in the normal course of events, it is unlikely their worlds would ever have intersected. Kathleen A. Roskot, 19, the daughter of middle-class parents on Long Island, was a star athlete on the Columbia University lacrosse team. Marie Jean-Paul, 39, known to her friends as Carol, grew up in Haiti, and worked as a nurse's aide at a hospital in Brooklyn. Joy Thomas, 18, graduated from Mount Vernon High School in June and was studying to be a teacher at Westchester Community College.

headline.main: When Women Find Love Is Fatal

docs.abstract: Women are frequently targets of homicidal attacks by men with whom they have had romantic relationships; FBI statistics show that 32 percent of 3,419 women killed in United States in 1998, latest year for which data are available, died at hands of a husband, former husband, boyfriend or former boyfriend; many experts believe that figure is much higher; photo shows coffin of Kathleen A Roskot, apparently killed by ex-boyfriend; graph shows female murder victims, 1976-1998 (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: A visibly incensed Bill Bradley lashed into Vice President Al Gore for turning sharply negative in recent days, accusing him of resorting to ''outrageous scare tactics'' in criticizing Mr. Bradley's plan for universal health care. Straying from his typically even-tempered manner, Mr. Bradley appeared red-faced and almost speechless with anger during a news conference he called to rebut accusations by Mr. Gore, printed today in The San Francisco Chronicle, that Mr. Bradley's health care plan would deprive people with H.I.V. and AIDS of health coverage.

headline.main: Bradley, Outraged, Defends His Health Plan

docs.abstract: Visibly angry Bill Bradley scores Vice Pres Al Gore, rival for Democratic presidential nomination, for turning sharply negative in recent days, news conference, San Francisco; accuses Gore of resorting to 'outrageous scare tactics' in criticizing his plan for universal health care; is especially angered by Gore's assertion that his plan would deprive those with HIV and AIDS of health coverage; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In a strong bid to dominate health care on the Internet, the Healtheon/WebMD Corporation agreed yesterday to buy two competitors, the Medical Manager Corporation and CareInsite Inc., both led by the New Jersey financier Martin J. Wygod, for $5.2 billion in Healtheon stock. The deal increased the potential of Healtheon, a start-up that has yet to make a profit. Its goal is to connect doctors, patients and insurers online and to cut sharply the enormous nonmedical costs of paperwork in the nation's trillion-dollar health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In response to the question ''what is more immoral than taxing people just because they fall in love?'' asked by Representative Tillie Fowler, the Florida Republican, regarding the bill passed by the House of Representatives to ease taxes for married couples (front page, Feb. 11), I offer this reply: How about not allowing two people in love to marry because they happen to be the same sex.
docs.abstract: Kevin Feldman letter questions why there is concern about morality of taxing married couples at higher rate, at time when same-sex couples cannot even marry
